subject: Re: New Zealand dialect
msgSnippet: ... So it will still be It-Key-See-Et-No-Tea? Demonstrably this has been somewhat improved. I used to think they would come out identical as I mentioned
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> > And thank goodness they were not believed: phonemic QS may be
> > serviceable but lexical set QS may work even better.
>
> (Heh, heh.) They're actually equivalent; with the exception of the
> special cases BATH and CLOTH, the lexical sets correspond to phonemes.
>

So it will still be It-Key-See-Et-No-Tea? Demonstrably this has been
somewhat improved.
I used to think they would come out identical as I mentioned
repeatedly and as my silent inclusion of IPA symbols in my charts was
meant to show. But lexical set produces slightly different results
than fixed phonemic mapping. For one thing Boston and West Coast will
now use the same letter for "lot" one pronouncing it /A/ the other as
/Q/. So yes, the lexical sets correspond to phonemes in 90% of cases
inside the US but still fewer across accents.
And yes, there is the BATH and CLOTH improvement.
I have to say they're not overwhelmingly huge improvements over fixed
phonetic mapping of letters though but progress is progress.

>
> They're just easier to grasp: people find it easier to think about
>lexical sets
>...
>(Snicker, snicker.)
>

Now you're joking.
